awd_titl_txt: Function and mechanism of action of plant-specific LINC complexes in pollen tube and guard cell biology.
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores the function of a new class of plant proteins that are involved in positioning the nucleus with the plant cell. The manner in which the position of the nucleus affects the function of plant cells is important for their life cycle and for their response to changing environmental conditions. This project will first explore the mechanisms by which nuclear position is controlled in the pollen tube, a structure that is essential for fertilization and thus the subsequent seed production in flowering plants. This project will also explore the role of the nuclear position in the cells that control the opening and closing of apertures (stomata) in the leaf of the plant, which regulate the movement of carbon dioxide from the air into the plant, and the loss of water (as vapor) from plant leaves into the air. The uptake of carbon dioxide from the air and the loss of water from the plant are of added significance in the face of increasingly frequent climate events such as drought, temperature extremes and the rising levels of carbon dioxide in the earth's atmosphere.

Plant-specific outer nuclear envelope proteins (KASH proteins) are the functional equivalent of animal KASH proteins of the linker of nucleoskeleton and cytoskeleton (LINC) complexes. This project will dissect how KASH proteins function in plant male fertility and guard cell function. One plant specific LINC complex is required to move the vegetative nucleus through the pollen tube and its disruption affects pollen tube termination and male fertility. The connection of this newly discovered process to known signaling pathways of pollen tube function will be determined. A second plant-specific LINC complex is involved in anchoring the nucleus in guard cells and its disruption changes guard cell actin organization, abiotic stress responses, and guard cell dynamics. The connection between guard cell nuclear position, cortical actin patterns and aperture regulation by biotic and abiotic signals will be investigated. Mathematical modeling and targeted genetic and biochemical approaches will be used to identify the motors, clarify the force requirements and define the mechanisms that control nuclear movement in pollen tube and guard cells.

por.por_cntn:
Nuclear movement and positioning play an important role in developmental processes throughout eukaryotic life. They are often mediated by a protein complex spanning the inner and outer membranes of the nuclear envelope, thus connecting proteins of the cytoplasm with those of the nucleoplasm (Linker of Nucleoskeleton and Cytoskeleton (LINC) complexes). LINC complexes consist of the inner nuclear membrane (INM) SUN proteins and the outer nuclear membrane (ONM) KASH proteins. Our lab has shown several years ago that plants have a different kind of KASH proteins compared to animals and fungi. We have shown that one type of plant LINC complex is important for moving nuclei through pollen tubes and another for regulating the opening and closing of stomata (leaf pores). The first is important for seed set (grain yield) and the second for plant resilience to drought and heat stress. Understanding the molecular mechanisms of LINC complex control of these processes will aid in their potential future adaptation to changing environmental conditions. 

Pollen tubes burst upon reception by the female tissue, stimulated by reactive oxygen species (ROS), and release the sperm cells. During this funding period, we demonstrated that in the absence of the pollen-relevant LINC complex, the ROS-induced burst is inhibited and that this correlates with increased distance of the nucleus to the pollen tube tip. We show that nuclear calcium fluctuations are also inhibited by this increased distance, but that this inhibition does not correlate on a single-cell basis with lack of burst, suggesting a more complex model than anticipated for the role of calcium.

Stomatal opening and closing regulates gas exchange in plants, controlled by biotic and abiotic stresses. Here, we show that loss of one type of plant LINC complex impairs control by an abiotic, but not by a biotic stress and that this relates to both calcium and actin regulation in stomata. The LINC complex acts, in a currently still unknown way, downstream of an abiotic stress hormone, but upstream of calcium and actin, both involved in this signaling. There are two flavors of this LINC complex, and their activities can be distinguished with regards to specific calcium and actin-remodeling phenotypes. We also show that the same loss-of function mutants are defective in microtubule reorganization in stomata, which in turn influence stomatal dynamics.

Observations since the 1950s have described targeted nuclear movement and positioning during symbiosis initiation between legumes and rhizobia, but it has not been established whether these movements are functional or incidental. We have now identified and characterized LINC complexes in the model legume Medicago truncatula.  Using a dominant-negative transgenic strategy, we have demonstrated that LINC complexes are necessary for proper nuclear shaping and movement in Medicago root hairs and are important for infection thread initiation and nodulation.

Protein targeting to the INM is one of the least understood protein targeting pathways. The INM LINC complex components and other INM proteins are important for chromatin organization and meiosis and have been implicated in human diseases. In animals and fungi, one mechanism for INM targeting is a modified version of a pathway that delivers soluble proteins to the nucleus. Here, we tested if such a pathway also exists in plants. To explore whether this pathway exists in plants, we tested if a signal that works for soluble protein import could redirect a membrane protein from the endoplasmic reticulum to the INM in plants and found that this was indeed the case. We then made a series of constructs that tested with nuclear import signals would work, and how they have to be placed in relation to the transmembrane domain. The outcomes allowed us to define a set of ?rules? for targeting a plant protein to the INM that can now be used to engineer specific functions of this important membrane surface.

As an integral part of this project, a science outreach activity was created through a collaboration with art faculty at OSU. In an undergraduate course for both biology and art students, plant biology experiments designed by the PI were performed and the students then challenged to create an art piece that would communicate the science to the general public. A public show is held at the end of each semester and visitors are asked in exit interviews to comment on their experience. The art piece created is then entered by the faculty-student collaborators to other juried shows. One exhibit has traveled to Latvia, while others have been shown at more local venues. Seven graduate students, one postdoctoral fellow and several undergraduate research assistants have been trained through this funding.
